fields.value: Common Bean variety releases in Africa

datasetContactAffiliation.value: International Center for Tropical Agriculture - CIAT

dsDescriptionValue.value: The Pan Africa Bean Research Alliance is a network of national agricultural research centers (NARS), and private and public sector institutions that work to deliver better beans with consumer and market preferred traits to farmers. The datasets presented here draw from 17 Sub Saharan countries that are members of PABRA. The dataset on released bean varieties is a collection of 357 bean varieties released by NARS and there characteristics. The dataset on bean varieties and the relationship to constraints provides the 357 bean varieties on the basis of resistance to constraints such as fungal, bacterial, viral, diseases and tolerance to abiotic stresses. There is also a dataset of bean varieties that have been released in more than one country, useful for moving seed from one country to another and facilitating regional trade. The dataset on Niche market traits provides the market defined classifications for bean trade in Sub Saharan Africa as well as varieties that fall into these classifications. The datasets are an update to the 2011 discussion on PABRAs achievement in breeding and delivery of bean varieties in Buruchara et. 2011 in pages 236 and 237 here: http://www.ajol.info/index.php/acsj/article/view/74168 . It is also an update to a follow up to this discussion in Muthoni, R. A., Andrade, R. 2015 on the performance of bean improvement programmes in sub-Saharan Africa from the perspectives of varietal output and adoption in chapter 8. here: http://dx.doi.org/10.1079/9781780644011.0148. The data is extracted from the PABRA M&E database available here (http://database.pabra-africa.org/?location=breeding).

publicationCitation.value: Muthoni, R. A., Andrade, R. The performance of bean improvement programmes in sub-Saharan Africa from the perspectives of varietal output and adoption. Chapter 8. CABI. 2015

Buruchara. R, Chirwa. R, Sperling. L, Mukankusi. C, Rubyogo. JC, Muthoni.R, & Abang. MM, 2011 Development and delivery of bean varieties in Africa: The Pan Africa Bean Research Alliance (PABRA) model African Crop Science Journal. ISSN: 1021-9730. pages 236 & 237.

country.value: Congo, the Democratic Republic of the

files.description: A summary of 357 released varieties in the periods 2003 to 2016 and from 17 countries in Sub Saharan Africa. The varieties are presented 4 year time periods.
files.label: 1. Number of varieties released.tab

dataFile.description: A summary of 357 released varieties in the periods 2003 to 2016 and from 17 countries in Sub Saharan Africa. The varieties are presented 4 year time periods.

files.description: A summary of the 357 released varieties.
files.label: 2. Bean varieties and their details.tab

dataFile.description: A summary of the 357 released varieties.

files.description:
The 357 released bean varieties in the collection were released and accepted by farmers on the basis of resistance to two or more production constraints that are either fungal, bacterial or viral diseases and tolerant to abiotic stresses like low soil fertility and drought.  The constraints are ordered into two clusters: Biotic constraints include; Anth=Anthracnose, ALS=Angular, Leaf Spot, CBB=Common bacterial blight, HB=Halo Blight, BCMV=Bean Common Mosaic virus, BSM=Bean Steam Maggot, Aphids spp, Ascchyta spp, Ascochyta spp, BSM, Pod borer, Rust, and WB=Web blight. Abiotic constraints include; Drought, Flooding, Lodging, Low soil fertility, Low soil acidity, Low soil PH, poor soils, and shattering.
Datasets for days to maturity and the growth habit as either Bush or climber are also presented.
files.label: 3. Constraints , growth habit and Days to mautrity.tab

dataFile.filename: 3. Constraints , growth habit and Days to mautrity.tab
dataFile.description:
The 357 released bean varieties in the collection were released and accepted by farmers on the basis of resistance to two or more production constraints that are either fungal, bacterial or viral diseases and tolerant to abiotic stresses like low soil fertility and drought.  The constraints are ordered into two clusters: Biotic constraints include; Anth=Anthracnose, ALS=Angular, Leaf Spot, CBB=Common bacterial blight, HB=Halo Blight, BCMV=Bean Common Mosaic virus, BSM=Bean Steam Maggot, Aphids spp, Ascchyta spp, Ascochyta spp, BSM, Pod borer, Rust, and WB=Web blight. Abiotic constraints include; Drought, Flooding, Lodging, Low soil fertility, Low soil acidity, Low soil PH, poor soils, and shattering.
Datasets for days to maturity and the growth habit as either Bush or climber are also presented.

files.description: Each bean variety in this dataset has been released in more than one country, a critical aspect, because this helps to move the seed of that specific variety from one country to another country where it has also been released. Thereby facilitating regional trade.
files.label: 4. Multiple bean variety releases across PABRA Countries.tab

dataFile.filename: 4. Multiple bean variety releases across PABRA Countries.tab
dataFile.description: Each bean variety in this dataset has been released in more than one country, a critical aspect, because this helps to move the seed of that specific variety from one country to another country where it has also been released. Thereby facilitating regional trade.

files.description: Five market defined classifications for beans traded in markets are the basis for this dataset. The classifications are Canning beans, Micro nutrient rich varieties, Green beans also known as Snap beans, Pre- cooked beans, and Climbing beans. Bean varieties are organized on the basis of these classifications and for each country where they are traded.
files.label: 5. Niche traits.tab

dataFile.description: Five market defined classifications for beans traded in markets are the basis for this dataset. The classifications are Canning beans, Micro nutrient rich varieties, Green beans also known as Snap beans, Pre- cooked beans, and Climbing beans. Bean varieties are organized on the basis of these classifications and for each country where they are traded.
